info.title: @weka-api
info.description:
The WEKA system provides a RESTful API, enabling efficient automation and integration into existing workflows or monitoring systems. To access the REST API documentation within the cluster, navigate to /api/v2/docs on port 14000 (e.g., https://weka01:14000/api/v2/docs).

For detailed guidance on using the REST API, including CLI command equivalents and related concepts, refer to the official documentation: Getting Started with the WEKA REST API.

Important: WEKA uses 64-bit numbers, which requires careful handling when interacting with the API across different programming languages. In JavaScript, for instance, the "json-bigint" library is recommended.

get.description: Returns a list of active cluster alerts to monitor the system's health. The list includes silenced alerts and can be filtered by severity level.

parameters.name: severity
parameters.description:
Filters alerts by a minimum severity level, including alerts of equal or higher severity.
The default is warning. Accepted values are debug, warning, minor, major, or critical.

200.description: A successful response returns a list of alert objects.

get.description: Returns a comprehensive list of all possible alert types that the system can generate.

200.description: A successful response returns a list of all possible alert types.

get.summary: List alert descriptions and recommended actions
get.description: Returns detailed descriptions and recommended troubleshooting actions for all possible alert types.

200.description: A successful response returns a list of alert types with their descriptions and recommended actions.

action.example: Disable this alert by running the set_example_alert_off manhole

get.summary: List all active alert mute rules
get.description: Returns all currently active alert mute rules. Muted alerts do not generate notifications.

200.description: A list of muted alert rules was successfully retrieved.

description.example: Alert is muted for the whole system

put.description:
Creates a rule to temporarily mute a specific type of alert.
This is useful for preventing notifications during maintenance or for known, non-critical issues.
The mute can be applied globally to an alert type or filtered to specific servers, containers, or processes.

parameters.name: alert_type
parameters.description: The type of alert to silence. A list of all possible alert types can be retrieved from the GET /alerts/types endpoint.

duration.description: Specifies the mute duration in seconds.

process.description: Mutes alerts for specific process IDs. This parameter applies only to process-specific alerts. If omitted or used on a non-process alert, all alerts of this type are muted. Provide a comma-separated list or repeat the parameter for multiple IDs.

container.description: Mutes alerts for specific container IDs. This parameter applies only to container-specific alerts. If omitted or used on a non-container alert, all alerts of this type are muted. Provide a comma-separated list or repeat the parameter for multiple IDs.

hostname.description: Mutes alerts for specific server IDs. This parameter applies only to server-specific alerts. If omitted or used on a non-server alert, all alerts of this type are muted. Provide a comma-separated list or repeat the parameter for multiple IDs.

comment.description: Specifies a comment to provide context for the mute action.

put.description: Expands the scope of an existing alert mute by adding specific processes, containers, or servers. This action allows for granular suppression of notifications for a particular alert type without modifying the entire entry.

parameters.name: alert_type
parameters.description: Specifies the alert type to mute. Run `weka alerts types` to list all possible types.

process.description: Mutes alerts for specific process IDs. This parameter applies only to process-specific alerts.

container.description: Mutes alerts for specific container IDs. This parameter applies only to container-specific alerts.

hostname.description: Mutes alerts for specific hostnames. This parameter applies only to server-specific alerts.

put.description: Selectively restore alerts for processes, containers, or servers by removing them from an active alert mute. This action reactivates notifications for the specified identifiers while keeping other components under the same alert type silenced.

parameters.name: alert_type
parameters.description: Specifies the alert type to mute. Run `weka alerts types` to list all possible types.

process.description: Unmutes alerts for specific process IDs. This parameter applies only to process-specific alerts.

container.description: Unmutes alerts for specific container IDs. This parameter applies only to container-specific alerts.

hostname.description: Unmutes alerts for specific hostnames. This parameter applies only to server-specific alerts.

put.description: Removes all active mute rules for a specific alert type, causing it to generate notifications again.

parameters.name: alert_type
parameters.description: The type of alert to reactivate. A list of all possible alert types can be retrieved from the GET /alerts/types endpoint.

get.description:
Query filesystem capacity metadata showing SSD and total capacity trends over time.
**Time Range Options (mutually exclusive):**
- Use `timeframe` for predefined ranges (7d, 30d, 90d, 180d, 365d, 1y)
- OR use `start_time`/`end_time` for custom date ranges

parameters.name: fs_uuid
parameters.description: Filesystem UUID

parameters.name: timeframe
parameters.description: Predefined timeframe (7d=last 7 days, 30d=last 30 days, etc.). Mutually exclusive with start_time/end_time.

parameters.name: start_time
parameters.description: Start time for custom range (ISO format YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS). Mutually exclusive with timeframe.

parameters.name: end_time
parameters.description: End time for custom range (ISO format YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS). Mutually exclusive with timeframe.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: Maximum number of records to return

used_total_capacity.description: Used total capacity in bytes (SSD + Object)

get.description:
Query filesystem capacity metadata for a specific snapshot access point or the latest metadata.

- If `access_point` is provided: returns metadata for that specific snapshot
- If `access_point` is not provided: returns the latest (most recent) metadata

parameters.description: Filesystem UUID

parameters.name: access_point
parameters.description: Snapshot access point (optional - if not provided, returns latest metadata)

get.description: Returns the configured default and maximum expiration times for access and refresh tokens. Token expiration ensures authentication credentials remain valid for a limited time, reducing risks such as unauthorized access and token misuse.

access_token_expiry.description: Default lifetime of access tokens in seconds.

refresh_token_expiry.description: Default lifetime of refresh tokens in seconds.

max_access_token_expiry.description: Maximum allowable lifetime of access tokens in seconds.

max_refresh_token_expiry.description: Maximum allowable lifetime of refresh tokens in seconds.

post.description: Configures the default and maximum expiration times for access and refresh tokens to maintain a secure, policy-aligned authentication environment. Best practices recommend setting access tokens to 5 minutes and refresh tokens to 2 weeks to balance security and usability.

access_token_expiry.description: Default lifetime of access tokens in seconds (shorter lifetimes reduce exposure to stale token risks).

refresh_token_expiry.description: Default lifetime of refresh tokens in seconds (balances security with minimal reauthentication burden).

max_access_token_expiry.description: Maximum allowable lifetime of access tokens in seconds.

max_refresh_token_expiry.description: Maximum allowable lifetime of refresh tokens in seconds.

get.description: Returns the current login banner text and enabled status. The login banner displays a customizable legal or security message on the GUI sign-in page to warn against unauthorized access and inform authorized users of their responsibilities and acceptable use policies.

enabled.description: Indicates whether the login banner is currently displayed on the sign-in page.

put.summary: Set or update the login banner
put.description: Creates or modifies the login banner containing a security statement or legal message displayed on the sign-in page. The statement can warn potential intruders about illegal activities while advising authorized users of their obligations regarding acceptable system use.

login_banner.description: The text to display in the login banner.

post.description: Activates the login banner so it displays on the GUI sign-in page, presenting the configured security or legal message to all users attempting to access the system.
Deactivates the login banner so it no longer displays on the GUI sign-in page. The banner text is preserved and can be re-enabled at any time.

access_token_expiry.description: Default lifetime of access tokens in seconds.

refresh_token_expiry.description: Default lifetime of refresh tokens in seconds.

put.summary: Upload custom CA certificate for cluster authentication
put.description: Uploads a custom Certificate Authority (CA) certificate to be used for secure cluster authentication with external services such as Vault. This certificate enables the cluster to verify the identity of external systems using TLS/SSL. If a certificate is already configured, this operation replaces it.

certificate.description: The PEM-encoded CA certificate content, including header and footer markers with newline characters.

delete.summary: Remove custom CA certificate from cluster
delete.description: Removes the configured custom CA certificate from the cluster. After removal, the cluster will revert to using the default certificate validation mechanism.

get.summary: Get CA certificate details and status
get.description: Returns comprehensive information about the cluster's currently configured CA certificate, including its status, certificate metadata, and content. Use this endpoint to verify certificate configuration and expiration dates.

enabled.description: Indicates whether a custom CA certificate is currently configured.

country.description: Country code from the certificate's subject.

state.description: State or province from the certificate's subject.

locality.description: City or locality from the certificate's subject.

organization.description: Organization name from the certificate's subject.

organization_unit.description: Organizational unit from the certificate's subject.

common_name.description: Common name (CN) from the certificate's subject.

email.description: Email address from the certificate's subject.

expired_date.description: Certificate expiration date in ISO 8601 format.

post.description: Creates a new security policy to regulate access to cluster management and POSIX data services. These policies strengthen security by permitting or blocking connections from specific client IP address ranges without requiring user authentication. Policies are evaluated in order of attachment, and updates do not affect active connections.

name.description: Unique identifier name for the security policy.

description.description: Human-readable explanation of the policy's purpose and scope.
description.example: Allows admin access from admin workstations

action.description: Action to apply when the policy matches (Allow or Deny). Default is Allow for whitelist implementation.

role.description: User roles that this policy applies to for API access. Leave empty to apply to all roles.

ip.description: IP address ranges for access control. Accepts individual IPs, CIDR notation (IP/mask), or IP ranges (IP1-IP2).

read_only.description: When true, restricts policy-matched connections to read-only operations.

get.description: Returns a comprehensive list of all CIDR-based security policies defined in the cluster. These policies control access to cluster management and POSIX data services based on client IP ranges.

200.description: List of security policies retrieved successfully.

get.description: Returns detailed configuration information for a specific security policy identified by its UUID. This includes the policy's name, description, action, roles, IP ranges, and read-only status.

parameters.name: policy
parameters.description: Unique identifier (UUID) of the security policy to retrieve.

delete.description: Permanently removes a security policy from the system. This operation does not affect currently active connections. The policy will no longer be evaluated for new connection attempts.

parameters.name: policy
parameters.description: Unique identifier (UUID) of the security policy to delete.

patch.description: Modifies the configuration of an existing security policy. You can replace entire role or IP lists, or incrementally add/remove specific entries. Changes take effect immediately for new connections but do not impact existing active sessions.

parameters.name: policy
parameters.description: Unique identifier (UUID) of the security policy to update.

name.description: Updated name for the security policy.

description.example: Allows admin access from admin workstations

action.description: Updated action when the policy matches (Allow or Deny).

role.description: Replaces all existing roles with the specified list. Use empty array to apply policy to all roles.

add_role.description: Adds specified roles to the existing role list without removing current entries.

remove_role.description: Removes specified roles from the existing role list.

ip.description: Replaces all existing IP ranges with the specified list. Accepts IPs, CIDR notation, or IP ranges.

add_ip.description: Adds specified IP ranges to the existing list without removing current entries.

remove_ip.description: Removes specified IP ranges from the existing list.

read_only.description: When true, restricts policy-matched connections to read-only operations.

post.description: Creates a new security policy by copying all configuration settings from an existing policy. The new policy requires a unique name but inherits all other properties including description, action, roles, IP ranges, and read-only status.

parameters.name: policy
parameters.description: Unique identifier (UUID) of the security policy to duplicate.

name.description: Unique name for the duplicated security policy.

get.description: Simulates how one or more security policies would evaluate a connection attempt for API access or cluster joining. Returns the resulting action (Allow/Deny), whether it was explicitly matched, and details of the matched policy. Use this endpoint to validate policy configurations before deployment.

action.description: Resulting action from policy evaluation (Allow or Deny).

read_only.description: Indicates if the matched policy enforces read-only access.

explicit.description: True if the result matched an explicit policy rule; false if the default policy was applied.

parameters.name: policies
parameters.description: List of security policy UUIDs to evaluate in the test.

parameters.name: ip
parameters.description: IP address to simulate the connection from (IPv4 or IPv6).

parameters.name: role
parameters.description: User role to simulate for API access evaluation.

parameters.name: join
parameters.description: When true, simulates a cluster join scenario instead of API access.

delete.summary: Remove all security policies from cluster join configuration
delete.description: Removes all security policies currently applied to the cluster join process for the specified mode (backend or client). This allows any container to join the cluster without IP-based security policy restrictions. The join secret authentication, if configured, remains active.

200.description: All join security policies removed successfully.

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: Cluster join mode - backend for server containers, client for POSIX clients.

get.summary: Get security policies for cluster joining
get.description: Returns the list of security policies currently applied when containers or clients attempt to join the cluster for the specified mode. These policies work in conjunction with join secret authentication to secure cluster membership.

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: Cluster join mode - backend for server containers, client for POSIX clients.

put.description: Configures the complete set of security policies for containers or clients joining the cluster, replacing any existing policy configuration. These policies are evaluated to determine whether a join attempt from a specific IP address should be allowed or denied. Works in conjunction with join secret authentication.

policies.description: List of security policy UUIDs to apply for cluster joining. Policies are evaluated in the order provided.

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: Cluster join mode - backend for server containers, client for POSIX clients.

post.summary: Attach security policies to cluster join configuration
post.description: Adds one or more security policies to the existing list of policies applied during cluster joining for the specified mode. The new policies are appended to the end of the evaluation order. Use this endpoint to incrementally build up join security without replacing the entire policy set.

200.description: Security policies attached successfully to join configuration.

policies.description: List of security policy UUIDs to add to the cluster join configuration.

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: Cluster join mode - backend for server containers, client for POSIX clients.

post.summary: Detach security policies from cluster join configuration
post.description: Removes specific security policies from the list of policies applied during cluster joining for the specified mode. Other policies in the join configuration remain active and continue to be evaluated in their original order.

200.description: Security policies detached successfully from join configuration.

policies.description: List of security policy UUIDs to remove from the cluster join configuration.

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: Cluster join mode - backend for server containers, client for POSIX clients.

get.description: Returns the currently configured idle timeout duration for the graphical user interface. The GUI idle timeout automatically logs out users after a specified period of inactivity, reducing the risk of unauthorized access from unattended sessions.

200.description: GUI idle timeout configuration retrieved successfully.

timeout.description: GUI idle timeout duration in seconds (valid range 60-86400).

put.description: Sets the duration after which inactive GUI sessions are automatically terminated. This security feature helps protect against unauthorized access by logging out users who leave their sessions unattended. The timeout value must be between 60 seconds (1 minute) and 86400 seconds (24 hours).

timeout.description: GUI idle timeout duration in seconds (minimum 60, maximum 86400).

delete.summary: Reset GUI idle timeout to default
delete.description: Restores the GUI idle timeout setting to its default system value, removing any custom configuration. This returns the timeout duration to the standard recommended setting for automatic session termination.

get.description:
Returns a comprehensive list of all servers within the cluster.
Supports optional filtering by server role to narrow results to specific server types or functions within the cluster topology.

parameters.name: role
parameters.description:
Filter servers by assigned role (for example, frontend, backend, compute, management).
Multiple roles can be specified to retrieve servers matching any of the provided values.

get.description: Returns detailed configuration, status, and operational information for a specific server identified by its unique identifier.

parameters.name: uid
parameters.description: Unique identifier for the server in UUID format.

put.description:
Initiates a specified action across one or more servers in the cluster.
This endpoint allows administrators to perform coordinated operations such as stopping, restarting, or applying
resource configuration changes to containers running on the targeted servers.
Actions are queued and executed based on cluster policies and operational constraints.

200.description: Action request submitted successfully and queued for execution.

server_identifiers.description: Collection of server identifiers targeting the servers for action execution. Accepts hostnames, fully qualified domain names, or IP addresses. All identifiers must correspond to active servers within the cluster.

requested_action.description: Action to execute on all containers running on the specified servers. STOP terminates container processes gracefully. RESTART performs a stop followed by start sequence. APPLY_RESOURCES updates container resource allocations without interrupting service.

timeout.description: Maximum duration in seconds to wait for action completion before timing out. If not specified, the system default timeout applies. Recommended values vary by action type - longer timeouts for RESTART operations, shorter for STOP.

get.description:
Returns comprehensive details about the existing SMB cluster, including
domain membership status, container assignments, ID mapping configuration,
encryption settings, and feature enablement flags.
Use this endpoint to audit the current cluster state or verify configuration changes.

symlink.description: Enable or disable symbolic link (symlink) support for the SMB cluster.

post.description:
Creates a new SMB cluster and establishes its foundational configuration. This includes setting the domain association, assigning containers to serve the SMB protocol, and defining security policies.
This operation creates the cluster structure but does not join it to an Active Directory domain. After the cluster is created, use the POST /smb/activeDirectory endpoint to complete the domain integration.

name.description: Unique identifier for the SMB cluster.

samba_hosts.description: Array of container UIDs that will provide SMB protocol services (minimum of three containers). These containers must be available and properly configured within the system.

domain.description: Fully qualified domain name (FQDN) for Active Directory integration.

samba_ips.description:
Floating IP addresses for high-availability SMB access.
These IPs must not be assigned to any container on the network.
Supported formats include A.B.C.D-E.F.G.H, A.B.C.D-F.G.H, A.B.C.D-G.H, or A.B.C.D-H.

domain_netbios_name.description: The domain NetBIOS name; If not given, the default will be the first part of the given domain name.

idmap_backend.description:
Defines the identity mapping backend strategy.
The rfc2307 strategy uses UID/GID attributes from Active Directory for persistent, deterministic mappings.
The rid strategy automatically generates mappings from Windows RIDs. This method requires no Active Directory configuration, but the mappings can change if ID ranges are modified.

default_domain_mapping_from_id.description: The SMB default domain first ID.

default_domain_mapping_to_id.description: The SMB default domain last ID.

symlink.description: Enable or disable symbolic link (symlink) support for the SMB cluster.

put.description:
Updates cluster-wide configuration parameters for an existing SMB deployment.
Supports modification of encryption policy and floating IP address assignments.
Changing the encryption policy affects new connections. Existing connections maintain their original encryption state until reconnection.

samba_ips.description:
An array of floating IP addresses or ranges that provide High Availability for the SMB service.
These IPs must be reserved and not assigned to any other server on the network. Ranges can be specified in formats like 192.168.1.10-20.

delete.description:
Disables the SMB cluster and removes its configuration. This action terminates all active client sessions, removes associated floating IPs, and automatically disconnects the cluster from its Active Directory domain, if joined.
The underlying filesystem data is preserved. This operation only removes network access through the SMB protocol.

get.description:
Returns all trusted domains configured within the SMB cluster.
Trusted domains enable cross-domain authentication and resource access in multi-domain
Active Directory environments. Each domain includes ID mapping range specifications.

post.description:
Registers a new trusted domain with the SMB cluster and configures its ID mapping range.
Trusted domains allow users and groups from additional Active Directory domains to access SMB resources.
This operation automatically restarts SMB services to apply the new trust configuration, which may cause a brief service interruption.
Ensure the specified ID mapping range (mapping_from_idmapping_to_id) does not overlap with existing domain ranges.

domain_name.description: Fully qualified domain name (FQDN) of the trusted domain to add.

mapping_from_id.description: Starting ID for this domain's UID/GID mapping range (must not overlap with existing ranges).

mapping_to_id.description: Ending ID for this domain's UID/GID mapping range (inclusive).

get.description:
Returns a comprehensive list of all shares configured within the SMB cluster.
Each share includes access permissions, encryption settings, filesystem mappings,
user access lists, and configuration parameters.

post.description:
Provisions a new share within the SMB cluster, mapping a filesystem path to a network-accessible share.
The share becomes immediately available to authorized users upon creation.
For access control, use the user_list_type and users parameters to define initial access permissions. After creating a user, additional users can be added using the POST /smb/users endpoint. For ACL options, use the map_acls parameter to determine how Windows ACLs are translated to filesystem permissions (posix, windows, or hybrid mode).

share_name.description: Network name for the share as it appears to SMB clients (example - \\server\share_name).

fs_name.description: Name of the source filesystem to share.

description.description: A description for SMB to show regarding the share.

sub_path.description: Directory path within the filesystem to share. Use "/" to share the entire filesystem root.

mount_options.description:
WARNING - ADVANCED OPTION - Custom mount parameters passed to the filesystem mount command.
Incorrect usage may result in data corruption or loss. Consult documentation before modifying.

file_create_mask.description: POSIX permission mask (octal notation) applied to newly created files. For example, 0744 grants owner (rwx), group (r), others (r) permissions.

directory_create_mask.description: POSIX permission mask (octal notation) applied to newly created directories. For example, 0755 grants owner (rwx), group (rx), others (rx) permissions.

acl.description: Enable Windows ACL support with automatic translation to POSIX ACLs where possible. Required for fine-grained Windows permission management.

hidden.description: Hide this share from network browse lists. Users can still access the share by specifying its full path.

allow_guest_access.description: Permit unauthenticated (guest) access to this share. Security consideration - guest access bypasses domain authentication.

obs_direct.description: A special mount option to bypass the time-based policies.

encryption.description: Share-specific encryption policy. Options include cluster_default (inherit cluster-level encryption setting), desired (encrypt if client supports it, otherwise allow unencrypted), or required (reject connections from clients that don't support encryption).

case_sensitivity.description: Enable case-sensitive filename handling. When true, "File.txt" and "file.txt" are treated as distinct files. Windows clients typically expect case-insensitive behavior.

read_only.description: Mount share as read-only, preventing all write operations regardless of user permissions.

users.description: An array of user names to be granted access to the share. The permission level for these users is determined by the user_list_type.

named_streams.description:
Enable Alternate Data Streams (ADS) support. Required for Windows applications that
store metadata in named streams (for example, zone identifiers, custom properties).

map_acls.description: ACL mapping strategy between Windows and POSIX permission models. Options include posix (store permissions as POSIX ACLs only), windows (store permissions as Windows ACLs with extended attributes), or hybrid (maintain both POSIX and Windows ACLs).

post.description:
Joins the SMB cluster to the Active Directory domain specified during the initial cluster creation.
This operation creates the necessary computer account in Active Directory, establishes trust, and enables authentication for domain users and groups.
Before using this endpoint, you must first create the SMB cluster using POST /smb.

username.description: Domain administrator account with privileges to join computers to the domain.

password.description: Password for the domain administrator account.

debug_mode.description:
Enables debug mode for the operation. When set to true, the command runs with increased logging verbosity, providing additional diagnostic and troubleshooting details.
This option is typically used to gather more granular information during issue investigation or testing.

server.description: Specific domain controller hostname or IP address. If omitted, the system will discover an available domain controller automatically.

create_computerOU.description: Organizational Unit (OU) distinguished name where the computer account will be created.

timeout.description:
Maximum time to wait for domain join completion to accommodate varying network and domain controller response times.
Supported formats include 3s (seconds), 2h (hours), 4m (minutes), 1d (days), 1w (weeks), or infinite/unlimited.

put.description:
Disconnects the SMB cluster from the Active Directory domain.
This action deletes the cluster account from Active Directory and terminates domain-based authentication, making shares immediately inaccessible to all domain users. Before leaving the domain, configure an alternative authentication method if you require continued access to the shares.
Administrator credentials may be necessary to complete the operation.

username.description: Domain administrator account with privileges to remove computer accounts (optional, depending on DC configuration).

password.description: Administrator password (required if username is provided).

debug_mode.description:
Enables debug mode for the operation. When set to true, the command runs with increased logging verbosity, providing additional diagnostic and troubleshooting details.
This option is typically used to gather more granular information during issue investigation or testing.

post.description:
Adjusts the debug logging level for SMB container processes on specified containers.
Higher debug levels increase logging verbosity, which is useful for troubleshooting but may impact performance.

debug_level.description:
The debug level ranging from 0 to 10. Debug level guidelines include:
- Level 0 for minimal logging (production default)
- Levels 1-3 for basic diagnostic information
- Levels 4-6 for detailed operation logging
- Levels 7-10 for verbose debugging (use temporarily for issue investigation)

samba_hosts.description: List of container UIDs to apply the debug level. If not specified, the debug level applies to all SMB cluster containers.

put.description:
Updates operational parameters for an existing SMB share.
Changes take effect immediately and apply to new client connections. Active sessions may need to reconnect to observe changes.
Only a subset of share properties can be modified after creation. To change immutable properties (for example, filesystem, sub_path), delete and recreate the share.

parameters.name: uid
parameters.description: Unique identifier of the share to modify.

hidden.description: Hide the share when viewing the list of system shares.

allow_guest_access.description: When guest access is allowed, authentication is not required for accessing the share.

delete.description:
Removes an SMB share from the cluster, terminating network access to the associated filesystem path.
Active client connections to this share are forcibly disconnected.
Underlying filesystem data remains intact. Only the SMB network share configuration is removed.

parameters.name: uid
parameters.description: Share UID.

delete.description:
Removes a trusted domain from the SMB cluster, revoking authentication and access rights for all users and groups within that domain.
This operation triggers a background restart of the SMB services, which may cause a brief service interruption. Before removing a domain, ensure no active share permissions reference its users or groups.

parameters.name: uid
parameters.description: Domain uid.

post.description:
Adds specified users or groups to a share's access control list with designated permission level.
Users can be Active Directory users, groups, or domain aliases.

parameters.name: share_uid
parameters.description: Unique identifier of the target share.

parameters.name: user_type
parameters.description:
Access permission category to add users to. User type options:
- read_only - Users can view and read files, but cannot modify content
- read_write - Users have full read and write access
- valid - Users explicitly allowed to access the share
- invalid - Users explicitly denied access (takes precedence over other permissions)

users.description: Users to add. Format - DOMAIN\username or DOMAIN\groupname.

delete.summary: Remove all users from the access list
delete.description:
Removes all users and groups from the specified access permission category for a given share.
This is a bulk operation that clears the entire user list for the specified category.
Useful when reconfiguring share permissions from scratch or removing all entries before applying a new access control policy.
To remove individual users, use DELETE /smb/users/{share_uid}/{user_type}/{user} instead.

parameters.name: share_uid
parameters.description: Share UID.

parameters.name: user_type
parameters.description:
Access permission category to add users to. User type options:
- read_only - Users can view and read files, but cannot modify content
- read_write - Users have full read and write access
- valid - Users explicitly allowed to access the share
- invalid - Users explicitly denied access (takes precedence over other permissions)

delete.summary: Remove specific user from share access
delete.description:
Removes an individual user or group from the specified access permission category.
The user immediately loses the associated permissions, but may retain access through other permission categories or group memberships.

parameters.name: share_uid
parameters.description: Share UID.

parameters.name: user_type
parameters.description: read_only, read_write, valid, invalid.

parameters.name: user
parameters.description: Username or group name to remove (format - DOMAIN\name, for example, "AD\jdoe").

get.description:
Checks the operational readiness of all containers participating in the SMB cluster.
The response indicates whether each container SMB process is fully operational and ready to serve client requests.
Use this endpoint to monitor cluster health or to verify that configuration changes have been applied successfully.

data.description: Map of container UIDs to their readiness status.

additionalProperties.description: true if container is ready, false if still initializing or encountering errors.

put.description:
Expands the SMB cluster by adding containers to distribute the SMB service load.
Newly added containers immediately handle SMB requests and participate in HA failover.
Requires properly configured hosts and sufficient floating IPs.
Used to scale SMB capacity for increased load or improved fault tolerance.

addedHosts.description: Array of container unique identifiers (UIDs) to add to the SMB cluster.

delete.description:
Removes specified containers from the SMB cluster. Client connections on the removed containers migrate to the remaining active containers in the cluster.
Use this operation to decommission containers for maintenance or to reduce the cluster size during periods of low demand.
Before proceeding, ensure that at least one container remains in the cluster and that the removal does not violate the cluster's minimum redundancy requirements.

parameters.name: removedHosts
parameters.description: Array of container unique identifiers (UIDs) to remove from the cluster.

post.description: Creates a new snapshot policy with specified scheduling parameters, retention rules, and configuration settings for automated point-in-time data copies.

name.description: Name of snapshot policy to create.

get.description: Returns a complete list of all snapshot policies configured in the cluster with their current settings and status.
Returns detailed configuration for a specific snapshot policy, including schedule definitions, retention parameters, and attached filesystem associations.

parameters.name: uid
parameters.description: snapshot policy uid.

put.description: Updates configuration settings for an existing snapshot policy, including name, description, schedule parameters, retention rules, and activation status.

parameters.name: uid
parameters.description: Snapshot policy uid.

delete.description: Permanently removes a snapshot policy from the system. All filesystems must be detached from the policy before deletion can proceed.

parameters.name: uid
parameters.description: Snapshot policy uid.

get.summary: List filesystems attached to a snapshot policy
get.description: Returns a list of all filesystem identifiers currently associated with a specific snapshot policy.

parameters.name: uid
parameters.description: Snapshot policy uid.

post.description: Associates one or more filesystems with a snapshot policy, applying the policy's scheduling and retention rules to the specified filesystems.

parameters.name: uid
parameters.description: Snapshot policy uid.

filesystems.description: A list of filesystem UIDs to attach.

post.description: Removes the association between a snapshot policy and one or more filesystems, discontinuing automated snapshot operations for those filesystems.

parameters.name: uid
parameters.description: Snapshot policy UID.

parameters.name: remove_waiting_tasks
parameters.description: Allow to delete all waiting tasks corresponding to the filesystems.

filesystems.description: A list of filesystem uids to detach.

post.description: Creates a copy of an existing snapshot policy with its configuration settings, optionally including filesystem associations. Useful for establishing similar policies with minor variations.

parameters.name: uid
parameters.description: Snapshot policy uid.

parameters.name: include_attached_filesystems
parameters.description: Define whether or not to include the attached filesystems.

name.description: Name of the new snapshot policy.

description.description: Description of the new snapshot policy.

post.summary: Run the snapshot policy schedule once
post.description: Runs a specified schedule type immediately, creating snapshots for all attached filesystems without waiting for the scheduled time.

parameters.name: uid
parameters.description: Snapshot policy uid

data.example: Background jobs are initiated to generate snapshots for all attached filesystems.

schedule_type.description: Schedule type to be run once.

get.description: Returns a list of all filesystem snapshots in the system. Snapshots are point-in-time copies used for backup, archiving, and testing. Filter results by filesystem using the query parameter.

parameters.name: filesystem
parameters.description: Filter by specific filesystem.

post.description:
Creates a point-in-time snapshot of an existing filesystem. Snapshots are read-only by default and do not impact system performance. Writable snapshots enable data modification for testing environments.
Snapshots consume minimal space based on 4KB granularity differences. Once created as writable, a snapshot cannot be converted to read-only.

fs_uid.description: Unique identifier of the filesystem to snapshot.

access_point.description: Access point directory name for mounting the snapshot.

source_snap_uid.description: Source snapshot identifier when creating a snapshot of an existing snapshot.

is_writable.description: Create a writable snapshot. Writable snapshots consume approximately twice the internal resources of read-only snapshots and cannot be converted to read-only.

get.description: Returns detailed information about a specific snapshot, including creation timestamp, parent filesystem, size, and writability status.

parameters.name: uid
parameters.description: Unique identifier of the snapshot (UUID format).

put.description: Modifies snapshot name or access point. The snapshot's data and point-in-time state remain unchanged.

parameters.name: uid
parameters.description: Unique identifier of the snapshot to update.

delete.description: Permanently removes a snapshot from the system and frees storage space consumed by its unique data. If the snapshot has been downloaded to another filesystem, deletion may cause that filesystem to malfunction. Ensure downloaded snapshots are un-tiered or migrated before deletion.

parameters.name: uid
parameters.description: Unique identifier of the snapshot to delete.

post.summary: Create a copy of a snapshot
post.description: Creates a duplicate of an existing snapshot within the same filesystem. Useful for creating multiple versions or preserving snapshot state.

parameters.name: uid
parameters.description: Unique identifier of the source snapshot to copy.

destination_name.description: Name for the newly created snapshot copy.

post.description: Transfers a snapshot to object storage using the Snap-To-Object feature. Consolidates all snapshot data, including filesystem metadata and files, for backup, archiving, or disaster recovery. Only read-only snapshots can be uploaded. Upload snapshots in chronological order for optimal efficiency.

extra.description: Additional metadata related to the upload operation.

locator.description: Unique locator string identifying the snapshot's location in object store. Required for downloading or restoring the snapshot.

parameters.name: uid
parameters.description: Unique identifier of the snapshot to upload.

obs_site.description: Destination object store site. LOCAL for co-located high-performance backup, REMOTE for geographic redundancy.

post.description: Downloads a previously uploaded snapshot from object storage to a filesystem. Enables data restoration, disaster recovery, and filesystem migration. Snapshots are incrementally reconstructed on the target filesystem. Apply snapshots in chronological order for optimal consistency. Use the locator obtained during snapshot upload. Downloading snapshots from object stores within the same cluster is not supported.

fs_uid.description: Unique identifier of the target filesystem.

locator.description: Unique locator string identifying the snapshot in object store (returned during upload).

name.description: Name to assign to the downloaded snapshot.

access_point.description: Access point directory name for mounting.

allow_non_chronological.description: Permit downloading snapshots in non-chronological order. Use with caution as this may affect data consistency.

allow_divergence.description: Allow downloading snapshots that are not descendants of the last downloaded snapshot. Use carefully to avoid data inconsistencies.

post.description: Restores a filesystem to a previous state using a specified snapshot. This operation overwrites the current filesystem content. This operation is destructive. Ensure appropriate backups exist before proceeding. Consider creating a snapshot of the current filesystem state first.

parameters.name: fs_uid
parameters.description: Unique identifier of the target filesystem to restore.

parameters.name: uid
parameters.description: Unique identifier of the source snapshot.

post.summary: Get snapshot metadata from object store
post.description: Returns detailed metadata about a snapshot stored in object storage using its locator string. Queries the object store directly without requiring the snapshot to be downloaded.

object_storage.description: Name or identifier of the object storage system.

locator.description: Unique locator string identifying the snapshot's location (returned during upload).

post.description: Prepares the system for computing differences between two snapshots by generating processing tokens (cookies). This is the first step in a two-phase operation for identifying changed, added, or deleted files. The operation divides the comparison workload into parallel chunks based on the requested parallelism. Use the returned cookies in subsequent getResults calls.

200.description: Differential analysis prepared successfully with cookie tokens.

fs_name.description: Name of the filesystem containing the snapshots.

recent_snap.description: Name of the newer snapshot (target state).

older_snap.description: Name of the older snapshot (baseline state). If omitted, compares against the immediately preceding snapshot.

parallelism.description: Number of parallel processing tokens to generate. Higher values enable greater parallelism. Recommended range 4-32.

post.description: Retrieves the actual differences between two snapshots, including changed, added, and deleted files. Must be called after preparing the differential analysis using the prepare endpoint. Supports efficient pagination through resume and stop tokens. Use resume_token from previous responses to continue where you left off.

fs_name.description: Name of the filesystem containing the snapshots.

older_snap.description: Name of the older snapshot. If omitted, defaults to the immediately preceding snapshot.

max_results.description: Maximum number of changed inodes to return. Balance between response size and round-trip.

resume_token.description: Token from previous response to continue pagination. Omit to start from the beginning.

stop_token.description: Token indicating where to stop. Used with resume_token for specific ranges, particularly when distributing work across parallel tasks.

output_type.description: Level of detail - DEFAULT (basic), PARTIAL_STAT (common statistics), or FULL_STAT (comprehensive metadata).

resolve_path.description: Include full filesystem path for each entry. Useful for reports, but adds processing overhead.

get.description: Returns statistics related to the cluster's performance and resource usage.

parameters.name: category
parameters.description: Array of categories.

get.description: Returns detailed information about the statistics.

description.example: Number of HTTP LENGTH_REQUIRED responses per second

get.description: Returns live statistics for the cluster.

get.summary: Get statistics retention and disk usage
get.description: Returns the retention period of statistics and the estimated disk space required for their storage.

parameters.name: retention_duration
parameters.description: Duration (format - 1 minute 2 seconds, options - weeks, days, hours, minutes, seconds).

post.description: Sets the duration for which statistics are retained in storage.

retention_duration.description: Duration (format - 1 minute 2 seconds, options - weeks, days, hours, minutes, seconds).

post.description: Initiates IO services across the entire cluster.

200.description: Successful initiation of cluster IO services.

resend_secs.description: Interval in seconds before resending the request, if required.

status.description: Current status of the IO service startup process.

completed.description: Indicates whether the IO services have been fully started.

post.description: Shuts down IO services across the entire cluster.

brutal_no_flush.description:
Immediately stops IO services without performing a graceful flush of ongoing operations.
This option may lead to data loss and must only be used under explicit guidance from the Customer Success Team.

200.description: Successful initiation of cluster IO shutdown.

resend_secs.description: Interval in seconds before resending the request, if required.

status.description: Current status of the IO service shutdown process.

completed.description: Indicates whether the IO services have been fully stopped.

get.description: Returns all background tasks currently running in the cluster, with optional filtering for waiting tasks.

parameters.name: show_waiting
parameters.description: Include tasks in waiting state.

post.description: Resumes execution of a previously paused background task.

parameters.name: uid
parameters.description: Task UUID.

post.description: Temporarily pauses a running background task. The task can be resumed later without losing progress.

parameters.name: uid
parameters.description: Task UUID.

post.description: Permanently terminates a background task and discards any incomplete work. This action cannot be undone.

parameters.name: uid
parameters.description: Task UUID.

get.description: Returns the current CPU resource limits configured for background task execution.

cpuPercentLimit.description: Maximum CPU percentage allocated to background tasks.

put.description: Configures the maximum CPU resources that can be allocated to background tasks cluster-wide.

cpu_limit.description: CPU percentage to allocate for background tasks (0-100).

get.description: Returns the cluster-wide telemetry configuration, including audit and forwarding settings.

post.description: Modifies cluster-wide telemetry settings, including enabling/disabling audit logging and configuring tracked operations.

enabled.description: Enable or disable the telemetry gateway.

audit_traces_enabled.description: Enable or disable audit trace collection.

resolve_full_file_paths.description: Include full file paths in telemetry data.

operations.description: Operations to track (use 'All' or specify individual operations like 'Open', 'Create', 'Delete').

get.description: Returns all configured export destinations for telemetry data (for example, Splunk, S3, Kafka).

put.description: Configures a new export destination to forward telemetry events to an external system.

get.description: Returns the configuration and status of a specific export destination.

parameters.name: uid
parameters.description: Unique export identifier (UUID format).

post.description: Modifies the configuration of an existing export destination (for example, endpoint URL, authentication credentials).

parameters.name: uid
parameters.description: Unique export identifier (UUID format).

delete.description: Removes an export destination, stopping all telemetry forwarding to that endpoint.

parameters.name: uid
parameters.description: Unique export identifier (UUID format).

put.description: Associates one or more data sources (for example, 'Audit') with an export destination to begin forwarding that data type.

parameters.name: uid
parameters.description: Unique export identifier (UUID format).

delete.description: Removes one or more data sources from an export destination, stopping the forwarding of that data type.

parameters.name: uid
parameters.description: Unique export identifier (UUID format).

get.description: Returns the current TLS configuration, including certificate details and status.

post.description: Uploads and enables a new TLS certificate and key for the cluster.

delete.description: Removes the current TLS certificate configuration from the cluster.

get.description: Returns the full TLS certificate configured for the cluster.
Returns the current trace collection settings, including status and storage limits for both server and client traces.

server_ensure_free.description: Minimum free space (in KB) to maintain on server storage.

client_ensure_free.description: Minimum free space (in KB) to maintain on client storage.

server_max.description: Maximum storage space (in KB) allocated for server traces.

client_max.description: Maximum storage space (in KB) allocated for client traces.

put.description: Updates trace collection parameters, including storage allocation limits and free space thresholds for server and client trace data.

delete.description: Restores all trace collection settings to their factory default values, including storage limits and collection status.

200.description: Trace configuration restored to defaults successfully.

get.description: Returns the configured freeze period during which trace data is preserved and protected from automatic deletion to support troubleshooting and investigation activities.

start_time.description: Start timestamp of the freeze period (ISO 8601 format).

end_time.description: End timestamp of the freeze period (ISO 8601 format).

freeze_retention.description: Duration (in days) to retain frozen trace data.

override_existing_period.description: Replace existing freeze period if one is already configured.

comment.description: Reference identifier or notes for the freeze period.

put.description: Configures a time range during which trace data is preserved and protected from deletion. This ensures diagnostic data remains available for analysis and troubleshooting of specific incidents or issues.

delete.description: Removes the active trace freeze configuration and allows frozen trace data to be subject to normal retention policies. This action clears all freeze period settings and releases preserved traces.

level.description: Trace verbosity level (LOW for essential data, HIGH for comprehensive diagnostic information).

put.description: Adjusts the granularity of trace data collection. LOW level captures essential information suitable for routine troubleshooting with minimal storage impact. HIGH level captures comprehensive diagnostic details required for complex issue analysis and root cause investigation.

get.description: Returns all local user accounts on the system.

post.description: Creates a new local user account with the specified credentials and permissions.

username.description: Unique username for the new account.

password.description: Password meeting complexity requirements (minimum 8 characters with at least one uppercase letter, one lowercase letter, and one number or special character).

posix_uid.description: POSIX UID for S3 file operations (S3 environments only).

posix_gid.description: POSIX GID for S3 file operations (S3 environments only).

put.description: Modifies role and POSIX settings for an existing local user.

parameters.name: uid
parameters.description: Unique user identifier (UUID format).

posix_uid.description: Updated POSIX UID for S3 file operations (S3 environments only).

posix_gid.description: Updated POSIX GID for S3 file operations (S3 environments only).

delete.description: Permanently removes a local user account and associated data from the system.

parameters.name: uid
parameters.description: Unique user identifier (UUID format).

put.description:
Updates a user's password. Users can change their own password with their current credentials.
Administrators can change any user's password within their organization.
Assigns a new password to a local user without requiring the current password. Requires administrative privileges.

parameters.name: uid
parameters.description: Unique user identifier (UUID format).

delete.description: Immediately invalidates all active authentication tokens for the specified user, terminating all GUI, CLI, and API sessions.
